questions.question: Sets store elements giving significance their order.
What happens when the code below is executed? fun main() { var list = listOf("1", "2", "3") list.add("4") list.forEach( print("%it ") } }
options: Error, add function is not a valid function for immutable lists.
Error, adding elements is not allowed because the list is tagged with var instead of val.

questions.question: From what interface does Collection inherits its operations to go through its elements?
Mutable collections must be tagged as var so that you can use its write operations.
Reassigning mutable collections that are tagged as val will cause an exception.
You can create a Collection that does not contain any element.
What is the result of executing the following code? fun main() { val myList = listOfInteger(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) println(myList) }
options: Error, there is no such function named listOfInteger().
Error, a list collection must be tagged with var.
Will execute and will display the structure of the list.

questions.question: What happens when the following code is executed? fun main() { var list = mutableListOf("1", "2", "3") list.add("4") println(list.elementAt(3)) }
options: Error, adding elements is not allowed because the list is tagged with var instead of val.

options: All of the other choices are correct.

questions.question: The Collection interface inherits from the Iteratable interface.
It is an unordered collection of unique items.
Collections can be used as function parameters.
It is a collection interface which provides operation for accessing collection elements.
These are groups of a variable number of items that share significance to the problem being solved.
What happens when the following code is executed? fun main(){ val list = mutableListOf("1", "2", "3") list.add("4") list.forEach{ print("%it") } }
options: Error, add function is not a valid function for mutable lists.
Error, adding elements is not allowed because the list is tagged with val instead of var.

questions.question: What function is used when retrieving collection elements at a specific position?
Which of the codes in the choices will execute?
options: fun printList(myList: List<Int>) { myList.forEach( print("${t "); } } fun main() { val list = listOf("1", "2", "3") printList(list) }
fun printList(myList: List<Char>) { myList.forEach( print("%$it "); } } fun main() { val list = listOf("1", "2", "3") printList(list) }
fun printList(myList: List<string>) { myList.forEach( print("%$it "); } } fun main() { val list = listOf("1", "2", "3") printList(list) }
fun printList(myList: List<Unit>) { myList.forEach( print("%$it "); } } fun main() { val list = listOf("1", "2", "3") printList(list) }

questions.question: Elements stored in a List does not follow a specified order.
Collections can be created without explicitly defining its data type.
It is an interface which provides not only operations to access collection elements but also write operations as well.
Collections in Kotlin can store items of different data types.
What happens when the code below is executed? fun printList(myList: List<String>(); myList.forEach{ print("$it ") } } fun main(){ val list = listOf("1", "2", "3") printList(list) }
options: Error, passing a list to a function is not allowed.
Will execute but will not print anything.
